name: Muslim Academy of Greater Orlando
mission: The mission of the Muslim Academy of Greater Orlando is to provide quality education of the highest standard in a safe, supportive, dynamic, and engaging Islamic environment so that students have the opportunity to excel to their fullest potential.
theoryOfChange: The school believes that an Islamic education (tarbiyah) breeds individuals of a different caliber who are prideful of their heritage and serve their community, achieved through a dynamic student-centered environment with high academic standards.
zakatClaimEvidence: No explicit mention of zakat on the Muslim Academy of Greater Orlando's donation pages or website. The donation platform states, "Muslim Academy of Greater Orlando hasn't set up any donation plans yet." (Source: https://magorlando.net/26-27-tuition-%26-fees)

ui_signals_v1.recommendation_rationale: Limited match due to weaker results and/or higher uncertainty; review methodology details before deciding.

components.improvement_suggestion: Add a dedicated zakat page or clearly state whether donations are zakat-eligible.
components.name: Muslim Donor Fit

components.improvement_suggestion: Expand services to underserved populations or geographies with limited nonprofit coverage.

alignment.rationale: Alignment 24/50: LOW Muslim donor fit, education global cause area

components.evidence: No beneficiary data available for cost-per-beneficiary scoring; moderate program ratio (≥65%)
components.improvement_suggestion: Publish beneficiary counts consistently so cost-effectiveness can be assessed.
components.name: Cost Per Beneficiary

components.improvement_suggestion: If reserves are above policy target, document why and publish triggers for planned deployment.
components.name: Financial Health

components.improvement_suggestion: Seek external evaluation or track outcomes over at least 3 years.
components.name: Evidence & Outcomes

judge_issues.message: The impact rationale does not adequately address the significant risk deduction due to the small board size (1 member). This is a key factor affecting the overall score and should be explicitly mentioned.

risks.risk_summary: Key concern: Board too small: 1 members

risks.description: No outcome measurement or metrics tracking

score_details.score_summary: Muslim Academy of Greater Orlando Inc shows moderate alignment and moderate impact (significant risk deductions applied).

all_citations.claim: The organization reported total revenue of $3,572,587 and a program expense ratio of 67.8%.
The charity holds 15.6 months of working capital and a fundraising efficiency of $0.00 per $1 raised.
The organization provides structured educational programs for students in the Greater Orlando area.
MAGO offers comprehensive education for students from Kindergarten through Grade 8.
The academy continues to serve the community with specific admission standards for middle school levels.
The organization accepts sadaqah and general charitable donations to support its educational mission.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The organization maintains a moderate overall score due to its solid financial stability and efficient fundraising, though its impact score is tempered by a focus on capacity building rather than direct high-scale intervention.
areas_for_improvement: Program expense ratio is lower than industry benchmarks for high-impact charities
Limited public data regarding specific long-term student outcomes or cost-per-beneficiary metrics

dimension_explanations.alignment: Alignment is rated as medium-low for general Muslim donors as the organization primarily serves a localized student body through tuition-based programs [3][8]. While it addresses the urgent cause of global education, its specific focus on a single academy limits its broader donor fit [2][6].
dimension_explanations.impact: The academy demonstrates moderate impact through its capacity-building approach to education, maintaining a program expense ratio of 67.8% [1]. While it provides essential schooling for local youth, the lack of specific cost-per-beneficiary data results in a medium impact rating [2][3].

baseline_narrative.headline: Empowering youth through a faith-based curriculum focused on virtue, wisdom, and academic strength.
strengths: High fundraising efficiency with a cost of $0.00 per $1 raised
Strong liquidity with 15.6 months of working capital
Comprehensive educational pathways from early childhood through middle school
baseline_narrative.summary: The Muslim Academy of Greater Orlando Inc (MAGO) is a dedicated educational institution providing quality instruction to children from Pre-K through Grade 8 [3][4]. With a mission centered on fostering virtue and wisdom, the organization reported a total revenue of $3,572,587 to support its academic programs and community services [1][2].

bbb_assessment.summary: The organization does not currently hold a BBB Wise Giving Alliance accreditation and fails basic governance standards due to board size.

case_against.mitigation_notes: The organization's long history since 2006 and consistent revenue growth suggest community-level vetting, despite formal governance gaps.
risk_factors: <cite id="1">Board consists of only 1 member</cite>, creating high key-person risk
<cite id="2">No third-party impact evaluations</cite> available to verify academic success
case_against.summary: The primary concern is the <cite id="1">lack of independent governance</cite> and limited transparency regarding educational outcomes.

confidence.notes: Financial health is clear, but governance and impact data are significantly lacking.

alignment.improvement: The organization could improve alignment by <cite id="8">clearly stating its sadaqah-only status</cite> on its donation pages to manage donor expectations.

credibility.explanation: While the academy is a long-standing institution <cite id="1">operating since 2006</cite>, its credibility is hampered by a <cite id="1">single-member board</cite> and a lack of independent transparency seals.
credibility.improvement: To strengthen credibility, the academy should <cite id="1">expand its board of directors</cite> to include at least five independent members and publish audited financial statements.

impact.improvement: Impact measurement would benefit from <cite id="2">publishing annual beneficiary counts</cite> and tracking student academic progress through standardized external evaluations.

strengths.detail: The organization operates with a <cite id="2">fundraising efficiency of $0.00 per $1 raised</cite>, ensuring that donor contributions are not eroded by solicitation costs.
MAGO maintains <cite id="2">15.6 months of working capital</cite>, significantly exceeding typical nonprofit benchmarks for financial health.
The academy has demonstrated a <cite id="1">3-year revenue CAGR of 25.5%</cite>, indicating strong community support and expanding operational capacity.

strengths_deep_dive: The Muslim Academy of Greater Orlando demonstrates remarkable financial resilience and growth. With <cite id="1">total assets reaching $3,270,864</cite> in 2024, the institution has successfully scaled its operations while maintaining a <cite id="2">67.8% program expense ratio</cite>. This efficiency is further highlighted by its <cite id="2">$0.00 fundraising cost</cite>, a rare metric that suggests the organization relies on organic community support and tuition rather than expensive marketing campaigns. Furthermore, the <cite id="1">$3,093,110 in contributions</cite> received in the most recent tax year underscores a high level of trust from its donor base.
rich_narrative.summary: The Muslim Academy of Greater Orlando (MAGO) is an educational institution <cite id="1">founded in 2006</cite> that provides a faith-based curriculum for students from <cite id="5">Pre-K through Grade 8</cite>. The organization operates with a mission to instill virtue, wisdom, and academic strength in its students, serving the Muslim community in Florida. In the 2024 fiscal year, the academy reported <cite id="1">total revenue of $3,572,587</cite>, representing a significant <cite id="1">3-year revenue CAGR of 25.5%</cite>. While the organization maintains a <cite id="2">67.8% program expense ratio</cite> in its primary reporting, it balances tuition-based services with <cite id="1">$3,093,110 in charitable contributions</cite>. The academy's educational model includes <cite id="3">service learning projects</cite> and a <cite id="4">professional development program</cite> for staff, ensuring that the institution grows alongside its student body. Financially, the organization is highly stable, maintaining <cite id="2">15.6 months of working capital</cite>, which provides a substantial buffer for long-term operational sustainability.
